questions.text: A 67 y/o male presented to the OPD with complaints of distended abdomen and pain in the right hypochondrium. On clinical examination, distended abdominal veins radiating from the umbilicus and a horse shoe shaped dull note was noted on the abdomen. Upon asking the patient, he said that since his mother had died in an accident, he used to consume alcohol every other day for his sorrows. What could be the likely cause of his condition:
questions.solution:
this is a classical case of cirrhosis of the liver since he has history of alcohol consumption. Due to this the liver produces less amounts of plasma proteins and this leads to generalized edema and collection of fluid in the abdominal cavity called ascites. Hence option C is correct.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.112)

questions.text: A person was diagnosed to have schistosomiasis. Which of the following cell you are most likely to find in the peripheral blood smear of the patient:
questions.solution:
Eosinophils, however, are often produced in large numbers in people with parasitic infections, and they migrate in large numbers into tissues diseased by parasites. Although most parasites are too large to be phagocytized by eosinophils or any other phagocytic cells, eosinophils attach themselves to the parasites by way of special surface molecules and release substances that kill many of the parasites. For instance, one of the most widespread infections is schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection found in as many as one third of the population of some developing countries in Asia, Africa, and South America; the parasite can invade any part of the body.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.430)

choices.text: reaction products due to plasma clotting

questions.text: Post diapedesis all of the following help in the movement of neutrophills toward the invading organism except:
questions.solution:
The process that is being reffered to here is chemotaxis and all the options are correct i.e. all of them help in the process. Hence the answer is option D.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.133)

choices.text: A: heme B: UDP-glucoronyl transferase C: stercobilin
A:heme B: UDP-gluccoronyl transferase C: urobilin

questions.text: The following image shows bilirubin metabolism. Label the parts A B and C.
questions.solution:
In the metabolism of hemoglobin to bilirubin the heme (A) is oxidized to biliverdin followed by bilirubin by heme oxygenase enzyme. Unconjugated bilirubin is conjugated by the enzyme UDP-glucoronyl transferase (B). and in the intestine the conjugated bilirubin is deconjugated to form urobilinogen and stercobilin (C) that gives the color to the stools.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.130)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding storage of blood:
1. RBC become spherical due to metabolic changes
2. ATP levels reduce and 2,3-diphosphoglycerate levels increase inside the RBC when stored.
3.granulocyte loose their phagocytic and bactericidal property in 10 days.
4.platelets become non functional in 2 days..potasium levels in the blood may also increase due to loss from inside the RBC to outside.
questions.solution:
Option C is correct since the statements 1,4 and 5 are true. Statement 2 is incorrect since both ATP and 2,3-diphosphoglycerate levels reduce when blood is stored. Statement 3 is also incorrect since granulocyte loose their phagocytic and bactericidal property in 4-6 hours and not 10 days. Hence options A and D are incorrect.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition pg.167)

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding PT:
1.as the level of prothrombin increase, PT increases
2.normal PT: 12 sec.
3.Each laboratory has its own PT to prothrombin concentration curve.
4.INR was designed to standardize the PT values.
5.PT will always be same for a patient when tested in the same laboratory.
6.manufacturer assings each batch of tissue factor a value between 1.0 and 2.0.
questions.solution:
Prothrombin time gives an indication of the concentration of prothrombin in the blood. More the concentration of prothrombin in the body, lesser is the PT (hence statement 1 is incorrect). The time required for coagulation to take place is known as the prothrombin time. The shortness of the time is determined mainly by prothrombin concentration. The normal prothrombin time is about 12 seconds. In each laboratory, a curve relating prothrombin concentration to prothrombin time, such as that shown in Figure 36-5, is drawn for the method used so that the prothrombin in the blood can be quantified. The results obtained for prothrombin time may vary considerably even in the same individual if there are differences in activity of the tissue factor and the analytical system used to perform the test (hence statement 5 is incorrect). Tissue factor is isolated from human tissues, such as placental tissue, and different batches may have different activity. The interntional normalized ratio (INR) was devised as a way to standardize measurements of prothrombin time. For each batch of tissue factor, the manufacturer assigns an international sensitivity index (ISI), which indicates the activity of the tissue factor with a standardized sample. The ISI usually varies between 1.0 and 2.0.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.460, 461).

choices.text: central skeleton of 9 microtubules called axoneme.
thin cell membrane covering the axoneme
a collection of microtubules in the proximal part of the tail.

questions.text: All of the following are present in tail of the sperm except:
questions.solution:
The tail of the sperm, called the flagellum, has three major components: (1) a central skeleton constructed of 11 microtubules, collectively called the axoneme-the structure of this is similar to that of cilia found on the surfaces of other types of cells described in Chapter 2; (2) a thin cell membrane covering the axoneme; and (3) a collection of mitochondria surrounding the axoneme in the proximal portion of the tail (called the body of the tail). Hence options A and C are wrong and hence option D is correct.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.975).

questions.text: A 12 y/o girl presented to the clinic with excessive facial hair and hair on the arms and legs. On examination her voice was quite deep and a mass was palpable on the back of the abdomen in the renal angle area. It was subsequently found that she had a tumor arising from the adrenal gland. What could be the likely condition:
questions.solution:
Secretion of Androgens Elsewhere in the Body. The term “androgen” means any steroid hormone that has masculinizing effects, including testosterone; it also includes male sex hormones produced elsewhere in the body besides the testes. For instance, the adrenal glands secrete at least five androgens, although the total masculinizing activity of all these is normally so slight (<5 percent of the total in the adult male) that even in women they do not cause significant masculine characteristics, except for causing growth of pubic and axillary hair. But when an adrenal tumor of the adrenal androgen-producing cells occurs, the quantity of androgenic hormones may then become great enough to cause all the usual male secondary sexual characteristics to occur even in the female. These effects are described in connection with the adrenogenital syndrome in Chapter 77. Phaeochromocytoma is a condition in which excess of catecholamines are produced in the body and this leads to marked rise in blood pressure of the patient. Diabetes insipidus is a condition due to reduced ADH or less response to it followed by excessive urination.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.980).

choices.text: causes growth of hair in pubic region
causes hair growth at the top of the head
causes development of acne in men

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding testosterone except:
questions.solution:
option B is the answer since the statement is incorrect. Testosterone does not cause the growth of hair at the top of the head and may be implied in cases of male pattern baldness. Rest all statements are true.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.981,982).

questions.text: label the parts A and B:
questions.solution:
option C is incorrect since graafian follicle is actually the mature fluid filled follicle that ruptures and results in the release of ovum(B). Once the ovum is released it leads to formation of corpus luteum (A) that produces progesterone.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.989).

choices.text: timely administration of human chorionic gonadotropin from outside.

questions.text: All of the following can lead to female sterility except:
questions.solution:
One of the most common causes of female sterility is endometriosis, a common condition in which endometrial tissue almost identical to that of the normal uterine endometrium grows and even menstruates in the pelvic cavity surrounding the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. Endometriosis causes fibrosis throughout the pelvis, and this fibrosis sometimes so enshrouds the ovaries that an ovum cannot be released into the abdominal cavity. Often, endometriosis occludes the fallopian tubes, either at the fimbriated ends or elsewhere along their extent. Another common cause of female infertility is salpingitis, that is, inflammation of the fallopian tubes; this causes fibrosis in the tubes, thereby occluding them. In the past, such inflammation occurred mainly as a result of gonococcal infection. But with modern therapy, this is becoming a less prevalent cause of female infertility. Still another cause of infertility is secretion of abnormal mucus by the uterine cervix. Ordinarily, at the time of ovulation, the hormonal environment of estrogen causes the secretion of mucus with special characteristics that allow rapid mobility of sperm into the uterus and actually guide the sperm up along mucous “threads.” Abnormalities of the cervix itself, such as low-grade infection or inflammation, or abnormal hormonal stimulation of the cervix, can lead to a viscous mucous plug that prevents fertilization.

Option C is actually one of the treatment modalities used for sterile females with hyposecretion from the pituitary gland.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 12th edition page.1001).

questions.text: The cells which surround the alveoli in the breast that causes the expulsion of milk in response oxytocin are called as:
questions.solution:
Myo-epithelial cells surround the alveoli and cause contraction of the alveolar cells to expulse the milk in response to the hormone oxytocin. Option B is incorrect since columnar cells are found in the ducts of other parts of the body and Option C is incorrect since these cells are found in the developing ovum in the ovaries.

(Ref. Guyton and Hall 2nd south-east asia edition page.695).

questions.text: A 28 years old female presented to the OPD with complaints of weight loss, hyperphagia, heat intolerance, anxiety, insomnia since past 3 months. On examination, exophthalmos is present, her skin is warm and soft; pulse pressure is high; fine tremor of the outstretched fingers is observed; and a BMR is +15. Lab investigations revealed antibodies to the TSH receptor. What is she suffering from?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient indicate towards hyperthyroidism. Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder common in young females characterised with symptoms of overactive thyroid gland. Antibodies to the TSH receptor,thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase are present in the patient.

Addison’s disease - amounts of ACTH is increased,

Cushing’s disease- Excess glucocorticoid secretion

Though SLE is also an auto-immune disease, the symptoms of the patient and the circulating antibodies in this patient is not suggestive of SLE. All ANAs, Anti-dsDNA, Anti-Sm, etc are seen in SLE.]

[Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.345; CLINICAL BOX 19–2;

choices.text: Acromegaly; intra pituitary growth hormone-secreting tumour

questions.text: A 45 years old male presented to the OPD with characteristic features like greatly enlarged hands and feet, vertebral changes attributable to osteoarthritis, soft tissue swelling, hirsutism, and protrusion of the brow and jaw. There was no mental retardation noted in this child. Lab investigations revealed increased prolactin levels and abnormal glucose tolerance. MRI revealed abnormal growth of internal organs. What is the most likely diagnosis and cause behind this?
questions.solution:
The presenting symptoms of this patient is suggestive of growth hormone excess.

The patient is 45 years old, hence this is most likely a case of Acromegaly not Gigantism.

Acromegaly can be caused by extra-pituitary as well as intra pituitary growth hormone–secreting tumours and by hypothalamic tumours that secrete GHRH, but the latter are rare.]

[Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.326; CLINICAL BOX 18-1

questions.text: A 38 years old male presented with complaints of frequent hallucinations. He was diagnosed to be suffering from Schizophrenia. He was started on typical antipsychotics (Dopamine receptor blockers). A month later, he came back to the hospital with breast enlargement and tenderness. What could be the reason of it?
questions.solution:
Hypothalamus releases Dopamine or prolactin inhibiting factor (PIF) Inhibits release of prolactin

Dopamine released from hypothalamus has an inhibitory effect on prolactin secretion. In this case, the patient was on medications which blocked the release of dopamine, thus, the inhibitory control of dopamine over prolactin was lost. This resulted into increased prolactin levels in the body causing gynaecomastia (breast enlargement and breast tenderness).

(1)- Dopamine levels can’t increase as the patient is on dopamine blockers.

(3)-the prolactin levels have increased, not decreased.]

[Ref:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 12th Edition; Page No. 883 Table 74-1

questions.text: A 7 years old child was found to possess inactivating mutations of the gene for renal 1α-hydroxylase. What is the child least likely to have?
questions.solution:
This child is suffering from rickets due to inactivating mutations of the gene for renal 1α-hydroxylase

1α-hydroxylase catalyses synthesis of the active form of vitamin D.

Inactivating mutation of this gene leads to rickets- Vitamin D deficiency.

Vitamin d deficiency is characterised weakness and bowing of weight-bearing bones, dental defects, and hypocalcaemia, not by Diabetes. Hence, option (4) is incorrect.]

[Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.378;

questions.text: A 55 years old post-menopausal diabetic hypothyroid, woman developed osteoporosis. She was diagnosed to be suffering from diabetes 2 years back and is not taking any treatment for the same. Which among these is least likely a reason for osteoporosis in this lady?
questions.solution:
Insulin increases bone formation, and there is significant bone loss in untreated diabetes.

Estrogen prevents osteoporosis by inhibiting the stimulatory effects of certain cytokines on osteoclasts. In post-menopausal women, estrogen level falls predisposing the lady to increased risk of osteoporosis.

Increased thyroid hormones (NOT HYPOTHROISISM) may cause hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and, in some instances, osteoporosis.

Hence, options (1) and (3) are correct

Option (2) is incorrect.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.383;

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presented to the OPD with frequent attacks of severe shortness of breath accompanied by chest tightness, pain and, wheezing. The graph B in the given figure depicts the patient's recordings during the forced vital capacity manoeuvre. What is the person most likely suffering from, and what type of disease is it?
questions.solution:
In obstructive lung disease, the FEV1/FVC RATIO is decreased, whereas, in restrictive lung disease, this ratio is either normal or increased. So, this graph shows obstructive lung disease.

The symptoms of the patients points towards asthma, which is a type of obstructive lung disease. Therefore, option (2) is correct.

Ref:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 12th Edition; Page No. 517, Figure 42-3

choices.text: If her condition is not managed well increased right ventricular afterload can lead eventually to right heart failure and death.
she most likely suffering from pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 30 years old female suffering from systemic lupus erythematosus, recently developed shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips and skin. Her pulse, is irregular with rate of 110/min. Als, her pulmonary vascular resistance was increased. What is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient indicate towards pulmonary hypertension, not asthma.

Also, SLE is a predisposing factor to pulmonary hypertension.

The causes of pulmonary hypertension include hypoxia, inhalation of cocaine, treatment with dexfenfluramine and related appetite-suppressing drugs that increase extracellular serotonin, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Some cases are familial and appear to be related to mutations that increase the sensitivity of pulmonary vessels to growth factors or cause deformations in the pulmonary vascular system. All these conditions lead to increased pulmonary vascular resistance. If appropriate therapy is not initiated, the increased right ventricular afterload can lead eventually to right heart failure and death.

Hence, both option (2) and (3) are correct.

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.632;

choices.text: A chronic condition characterized by lung cysts and densities (bronchopulmonary dysplasia) develops in some infants treated with O2 for respiratory distress syndrome.
complication in these infants is retinopathy of prematurity (retrolental fibroplasia)
High risk of manifestation of O2 toxicity.
retinopathy of prematurity can be prevented or ameliorated by treatment with vitamin C.

questions.text: A prematurely born infant is being treated with O2for Hyaline membrane disease. Which of the following statement is not true regarding in this context?
questions.solution:
A chronic condition characterized by lung cysts and densities (bronchopulmonary dysplasia) develops in some infants treated with O2 for respiratory distress syndrome. This syndrome may be a manifestation of O2 toxicity.

Another complication in these infants is retinopathy of prematurity (retrolental fibroplasia), the formation of opaque vascular tissue in the eyes, which can lead to serious visual defects. The retinal receptors mature from the centre to the periphery of the retina, and they use considerable O2. This causes the retina to become vascularized in an orderly manner. Oxygen treatment before maturation is complete provides the needed O2 to the photoreceptors, and consequently the normal vascular pattern fails to develop.

Evidence indicates that this condition can be prevented or ameliorated by treatment with vitamin E, which exerts an anti-oxidant effect.

In option (4), Vitamin C is mentioned, instead of vitamin E. Hence, that is incorrect.

All the other options are correct.]

[Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th Edition; Page No.642;

choices.text: the patient is suffering from sleep apnea
Apneic episodes are most common during REM sleep, when the muscles are most hypotonic.

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient complains of difficulty in breathing during sleep. He frequently wakes up while sleeping takes a few normal breaths, and falls back to sleep. He also complains of loud snoring, morning headaches, fatigue, and daytime sleepiness. What among the following statements is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patients are consistent with seep apnoea, so he is likely to be suffering from Sleep apnoea.

choices.text: it has only about one-fifth the narcotic effect of nitrogen
only about one half as much volume of helium dissolves in the body tissues as nitrogen
he low density of helium (one seventh the density of nitrogen) keeps the airway resistance for breathing at a minimum

questions.text: Why do deep sea divers use helium in the gas mixture instead of nitrogen during deep dives?
questions.solution:
In very deep dives, especially during saturation diving, helium is usually used in the gas mixture instead of nitrogen for three reasons:

(i) it has only about one fifth the narcotic effect of nitrogen;

(ii) only about one half as much volume of helium dissolves in the body tissues as nitrogen, and the volume that does dissolve diffuses out of the tissues during decompression several times as rapidly as does nitrogen, thus reducing the problem of decompression sickness; and

(iii) the low density of helium (one seventh the density of nitrogen) keeps the airway resistance for breathing at a minimum, which is very important because highly compressed nitrogen is so dense that airway resistance can become extreme, sometimes making the work of breathing beyond endurance.

Hence, for all the given reasons,helium is used in the gas mixture instead of nitrogen.

Ref:- Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 12th Edition; Page No. 538;

questions.text: A PATIENT IS SUFFERING FROM DAYTIME SLEEPINESS AND IS BEEN DIAGNOSED OF OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNOEA. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS FALSE REGARDING SLEEP APNEA
questions.solution:
THE PATIENT USUALLY SNORES AS SOON AS PATIENT FALLS ASLEEP

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a disorder caused by the repetitive collapse of the upper airway during sleep. It is the most commonTrusted Source sleep-related breathing disorder.

OSA occurs when the muscles supporting the soft tissues in your throat, such as your tongue and soft palate, relax. This causes your airway to narrow or even close, momentarily cutting off your breathing.

Normally, air should flow smoothly from the mouth and nose into the lungs at all times, including during sleep.

Periods when breathing stops completely are called apnea or apneic episodes. In OSA, the normal flow of air is repeatedly stopped throughout the night.

OSA is most common among older males, but it can affect anyone, including children. The incidence rises following menopause, such that the rates are similar in men and postmenopausal women.

Snoring is often associated with OSA, especially if the snoring is interrupted by periods of silence. Snoring is caused by airflow squeezing through the narrowed airway space.

It is important to remember that snoring doesn’t necessarily indicate something potentially serious, and not everyone who snores has OSA.

A diagnosis of sleep apnea begins with a complete history and physical examination. A history of daytime sleepiness and snoring are important clues.

ALL OTHER STATEMENT ARE TRUE

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th editionPG 276

Too much fat in your feces is called steatorrhea.

It may be a result of overconsumption of fatty and greasy foods, or it can be a sign of malabsorption. This means your body either isn’t absorbing nutrients properly or isn’t making the enzymes or bile needed to digest food effectively.

choices.text: THERE IS STIMULATION OF SMOOTH MUSCLE WHICH DECREASE INTESTINAL MOTILITY
IT IS DUE TO ACTIVATION OF OPIOID RECEPTOR
THERE IS DIFFUSE INCREASE IN PERISTALTIC ACTICITY OF SMALL INTESTINE
REFLEX EXCITATION DUE TO INCREASED DISCHARGE OF NORADRENERGIC FIBERS

questions.text: A PATIENT HAS UNDERGONE SUGERY OF ABDOMEN. THE PATIENT HAS PARALYTIC ILEUS AFTER THE SURGERY. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS TRUE FOR PARALYTIC ILEUS
questions.solution:
THE TRUE STATEMENT FOR OTHER OPTION IS AS FOLLOWS

A)THERE IS INHIBITION OF SMOOTH MUSCLE WHICH DECREASE INTESTINAL MOTILITY

C)THERE IS DIFFUSE DECREASE IN PERISTALTIC ACTICITY OF SMALL INTESTINE

D)REFLEX INHIBITION DUE TO INCREASED DISCHARGE OF NORADRENERGIC FIBERS

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG 502

choices.text: STEREOGNOSIS IS PERCEPTION OF FORM AND NATURE OF OBJECT WHILE LOOKING AT IT
DORSAL COLUMN IS DAMAGED IN THE GIVEN CASE
THE ABILITY OF STEREOGNOSIS DEPENDS ONLY ON INTACT TOUCH SENSATION
DAMAGE TO PRIMARY SENSORY CORTEX CANNOT LEADTO IMPAIRED STEREOGNOSIS

questions.text: A PATIENT IS EXAMINED FOR HIS CNS ACTIVITY AND NORMAL FUNCTIONING OF NERVES AND MUSCLE FIBERS. THE PATIENT IS DIAGNOSED OF TACTILE AGNOSIA. WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT IS TRUE
questions.solution:
DORSAL COLUMN RESPONSIBLE TO CARRY TOCH AND PRESSURE SENSATION THEREFORE ITS DAMAGE LEADS TO TACTILE AGNOSIA

THE TRUE STATEMENT FOR OTHER OPTIONS IS AS FOLOWS

A)STEREOGNOSIS IS PERCEPTION OF FORM AND NATURE OF OBJECT WHITHOUT LOOKING AT IT

C)THE ABILITY OF STEREOGNOSIS DEPENDS ON INTACT TOUCH AND PRESSURE SENSATION

D)DAMAGE TO PRIMARY SENSORY CORTEX CAN LEADTO IMPAIRED STEREOGNOSIS

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG164

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING ARE CORRECTLY MATCHED RECEPTORS AND THE STIMULUS THEY RESPOND TO
questions.solution:
THE RIGHT MATCH IS AS FOLLOWS

MERKEL CELL- SUSTAINED PRESSURE AND TOUCH

RUFFINI CORPUSCLE- SUSTAINED PRESSURE

PACINIAN CORPUSCLE- DEEP PRESSURE AND FAST VIBRATION

MEISSNER CORPUSCLE- SLOW VIBRATION

Ref : ganong review of medical physiology 25th edition PG160

choices.text: A-DYNAMIC FIBRE,B-GROUP Ia FIBRE,C-GROUP II FIBRE,D- STATIC FIBRE
A-GROUP Ia FIBRE,B-GROUP II FIBRE,C-STATIC FIBRE,D-DYNAMIC FIBRE
A-STATIC FIBRE,B- DYNAMIC FIBRE,C- GROUP II FIBRE,D- GROUP Ia FIBRE
A-DYNAMIC FIBRE,B- STATIC FIBRE,C-GROUP Ia FIBRE,D-GROUP II FIBRE

questions.text: IDENTIFY THE LABELINGS IN THE GIVEN IMAGE
questions.solution:
Division of the Intrafusal Fibers into Nuclear Bag and Nuclear Chain Fibers—Dynamic and Static Responses of the Muscle Spindle. There are also two types of muscle spindle intrafusal fibers: (1) nuclear bag muscle fibers (one to three in each spindle), in which several muscle fiber nuclei are congregated in expanded “bags” in the central portion of the receptor area, as shown by the top fiber in Figure 54-4, and (2) nuclear chain fibers (three to nine), which are about half as large in diameter and half as long as the nuclear bag fibers and have nuclei aligned in a chain throughout the receptor area, as shown by the bottom fiber in the figure. The primary sensory nerve ending (the 17-micrometer sensory fiber) is excited by both the nuclear bag intrafusal fibers and the nuclear chain fibers. Conversely, the secondary ending (the 8-micrometer sensory fiber) is usually excited only by nuclear chain fibers. These relations are shown in Figure 54-4.

Ref : Guyton and hall textbook of medical physiology 12 th edition PG 657

questions.text: IN A PATIENT WITH LONG QT SYNDROME, WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING WILL NOT BE OBSERVED?
questions.solution:
IN PEOPLE WITH LONG QT SYNDROME, THERE IS IRREGULAR CARDIAC REPOLARIZATION, INCREASED INCIDENCE OF VENTRICULAR ARRHYTHMIAS, DECREASED FUNCTION OF K+ CHANNELS AND INCREASED FUNCTION OF NA+ CHANNELS.

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1207

questions.text: IN RECORDING THE ECG OF A PATIENT, THE FOLLOWING VALUES WERE OBSERVEDPR INTERVAL- 0.18 SECONDSQRS DURATION- 0.08 SECONDSQT INTERVAL- 0.50 SECONDSOUT OF THESE VALUES, WHICH VALUE IS ABNORMAL?
questions.solution:
NORMAL QT INTERVAL IS UPTO 0.43 SECONDS, WHILE THE GIVEN VALUE IS 0.50 SECONDS. SO IT IS ABNORMAL.

REST NORMAL RANGE IS,

PR INTERVAL - 0.12 TO 0.20 S

QRS DURATION - UPTO 0.10 S

ST INTERVAL - 0.32 S

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1189 TABLE 29-2

questions.text: A 62 Y/O MALE PATIENT PRESENTED TO THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT WITH ACUTE CHEST PAIN AND RADIATION TO LEFT ARM. ON ECG RECORDINGS, THE FOLLOWING WAS SEEN. WHAT IS THE MOST LIKELY DIAGNOSIS?
questions.solution:
LEAD 1, aVL AND V 3-6 SHOW ST SEGMENT ELEVATION, SO THE ECG SHOWS STEMI (ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION)

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1212 FIGURE 29-17

questions.text: INCREASE IN CARDIAC OUTPUT CAN BE SEEN IN ALL EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
IN RAPID ARRHYTHMIAS DUE TO HIGH HEART RATE, THERE IS LESS TIME AVAILABLE FOR VENTRICULAR FILLING SO THE END DIASTOLIC VOLUME IS LOW, AS A RESULT THE CARDIAC OUTPUT IS ALSO LOW.

IN OTHER OPTIONS, A HIGH CARDIAC OUTPUT CAN BE SEEN

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO:1234 TABLE 30-3

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS NOT A FEATURE OF HYPOVOLEMIC SHOCK?
questions.solution:
CONTINUOUS TACHYCARDIA IS NOT SEEN. TACHYCARDIA FOLLOWED BY BRADYCARDIA IS SEEN.

IN HYPOVOLEMIC SHOCK, INITIALLY DUE TO BLOOD LOSS THERE IS SYMPATHETIC ACTIVATION AND TACHYCARDIA CAN BE SEEN AS A REFLEX. BUT WITH MORE SEVERE BLOOD LOSS, TACHYCARDIA IS REPLACED BY BRADYCARDIA, PRESUMABLY DUE TO A VAGALLY MEDIATED DEPRESSOR REFLEX.

REST FEATURES ARE CHARACTERISTIC OF HYPOVOLEMIC SHOCK.

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1244, CLINICAL BOX 30-2

choices.text: IT IS DUE TO ACCELERATED AV CONDUCTION
ABERRANT MUSCULAR TISSUE IS PRESENT BETWEEN ATRIA AND VENTRICLES
BUNDLE OF KENT CONDUCTS MORE RAPIDLY THAN AV NODE

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING STATEMENTS ARE INCORRECT ABOUT WPW SYNDROME?
questions.solution:
IN WPW (WOLFF-PARKINSON-WHITE SYNDROME, THE MANIFESTATIONS ARE SHORT PR INTERVAL, PROLONGED QRS DEFLECTION SLURRED ON THE UPSTROKE WITH NORMAL INTERVAL BETWEEN THE START OF THE P WAVE AND END OF THE QRS COMPLEX.

REST ARE CORRECT STATEMENTS

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1207

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING VALUES ARE CORRECTLY MATCHED?
questions.solution:
THE RIGHT VALUES ARE-

END DIASTOLIC VOLUME - 130 ML

EJECTION FRACTION- 65%

CARDIAC CYCLE (AT HEART RATE 75BPM) - 0.80S

ABSOLUTE REFRACTORY PERIOD ( HR-75 BPM) - 0.20S

REFERENCE: GANONG’S REVIEW OF MEDICAL PHYSIOLOGY, 26TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 1224, 1226, TABLE 30-1

questions.text: WHAT IS THE MAXIMUM POSSIBLE CARDIAC OUTPUT IN AN AVERAGE MALE MARATHONER?
questions.solution:
5 L/MIN IS THE NORMAL CARDIAC OUTPUT 23 L/MIN IS THE MAXIMUM CARDIAC OUTPUT DURING EXERCISE IN A YOUNG UNTRAINED MAN 30 L/MIN IS THE MAXIMUM CARDIAC OUTPUT IN AN AVERAGE MALE MARATHONER

REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:1038

choices.text: 0.2 L IS STORED AS AIR IN LUNGS
1L IS STORED COMBINED WITH HEMOGLOBIN IN BLOOD
0.5 L STORED IN MUSCLE FIBERS

questions.text: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS CORRECT ABOUT THE STORAGE OF OXYGEN IN DIFFERENT PARTS IN THE BODY?
questions.solution:
The body normally contains about 2 liters of stored oxygen that can be used for aerobic metabolism even without breathing any new oxygen. This stored oxygen consists of the following: (1) 0.5 liter in the air of the lungs, (2) 0.25 liter dissolved in the body fluids, (3) 1 liter combined with the hemoglobin of the blood, and (4) 0.3 liter stored in the muscle fibers themselves, combined mainly with myoglobin, an oxygen-binding chemical similar to hemoglobin.

REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:1034

choices.text: INCREASE IN STROKE VOLUME AT REST

questions.text: IN AN ATHLETE, WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING CHANGES IN THE CARDIOVASCULAR SYSTEM WOULD NOT BE OBSERVED?
questions.solution:
The maximum heart rate of an athelete increases, not decrease.

The stroke volume increases from 105 to 162 milliliters, an increase of about 50 percent,whereas the heart rate increases from 50 to 185 beats/min,an increase of 270 percent. Therefore, the heart rate increase accounts by far for a greater proportion of the increase in cardiac output than does the increase in stroke volume during strenuous exercise. achieved by untrained persons.The heart chambers of marathoners enlarge about 40 percent; along with this enlargement of the chambers,the heart mass also increases 40 percent or more.

But, the resting heart rate of an athlete is lower than that of a person who does not do physical exercise.

REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:1039

choices.text: MORE SLOW TWITCH MUSCLES COMPARED TO FAST TWITCH MUSCLES

questions.text: WHAT WOULD BE DIFFERENT IN AN ATHLETE COMPARED TO A NORMAL PERSON?
questions.solution:
THERE ARE MANY PHYSIOLOGICAL CHANGES THAT OCCUR IN AN ATHLETE’S BODY COMPARED TO A NORMAL PERSON’S BODY. OUT OF THEM THERE IS THE CHANGE THAT THERE ARE MORE SLOW TWITCH MUSCLE FIBERS COMPARED TO FAST TWITCH MUSCLE FIBERS, WHEREAS IN NORMAL PEOPLE THE NUMBER OF FAST TWITCH MUSCLE FIBERS IS GREATER. OTHER OPTIONS ARE INCORRECT AS ATHLETES HAVE, GREATER MUSCLE MASS (MUSCLE HYPERTROPHY), INCREASED OXYGEN CONSUMPTION, INCREASED BREATHING CAPACITY.

REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:1036

questions.text: IN THE FOLLOWING FIGURE, GUESS THE LABEL MARKED 'A'
questions.solution:
DURING HEAVY EXERCISE, THE CORE BODY TEMPERATURE RISES THE MOST. CORE BODY TEMPERATURE DURING LOW OR MODERATE EXERCISE WOULD BE IN THE NORMAL RANGE OR SLIGHTLY HIGHER THAN NORMAL. THE BODY TEMPERATURE DURING NIGHT SLIGHTLY RISES DUE TO THE DIURNAL VARIATION, BUT IS MOSTLY WITHIN THE NORMAL RANGE.

REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:867, FIGURE 73-1

questions.text: A GYM GOING LADY HAS COME TO YOU TO KNOW THAT DIET RICH IN WHICH CONSTITUENT CAN HAVE THE BEST RECOVERY IN MUSCLE ENERGY STORES AFTER EXERCISE. WHAT IS YOUR ANSWER?
questions.solution:
Recovery from exhaustive muscle glycogen depletion is not a simple matter. This often requires days, rather than the seconds, minutes, or hours required for recovery of the phosphagen and lactic acid metabolic systems. The recovery process occurs best: first, in people on a high-carbohydrate diet; second, in people on a high-fat, high-protein diet; and third, in people with no food. Note that on a high-carbohydrate diet, full recovery occurs in about 2 days. Conversely, people on a high-fat, high-protein diet or on no food at all show very little recovery even after as long as 5 days.

REFERENCE: GUYTON AND HALL TWELFTH EDITION, PAGE NO:1034
